revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = Taskwarrior | title = | logo = Taskwarrior logo.png<!-- Image name is enough --> | screenshot = Taskwarrior screenshot.png<!-- Image name is enough --> | caption = Taskwarrior 1.9.x demonstrating colored themes. | author = Paul Beckingham | developer = Paul Beckingham, Federico Hernandez, David J Patrick, John Florian, Cory Donnelly, Johannes Schlatow, Dirk Deimeke, Scott Kostyshak, Renato Alves, Wim Schuermann, Tomas Babej | released = {{Start date and age|2008|06|03|df=yes}} | discontinued = | latest release version = 2.5.1 | latest release date = {{Start date and age|2016|02|24|df=yes}} | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes}} --> | status = Active | programming language = [[C++]]<ref>[https://git.tasktools.org/projects/TM/repos/task/browse Taskwarrior Git Repository]</ref> | operating system = [[Windows]] (Cygwin), [[Linux]], [[Mac OS X]], [[BSD]] | platform = | size = | language = English | language count = <!-- Number only --> | language footnote = | genre = [[Task management]], [[Time management]] | license = [[MIT License]] | website = {{URL|https://taskwarrior.org}} }} '''Taskwarrior''' is an open-source, cross platform [[Time management|time]] and [[task management]] tool. It has a [[command-line interface]] rather than a [[graphical user interface]].
Taskwarrior uses concepts and techniques described in ''[[Getting Things Done]]'' by [[David Allen (author)|David Allen]], but is paradigm-agnostic in that it does not require users to adhere to any given life-management philosophy.<ref>https://taskwarrior.org/docs/start.html</ref>
According to its author, Taskwarrior was created "to address layout and feature issues"<ref>[http://taskwarrior.org/wiki/taskwarrior/About About Taskwarrior], {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100408100712/http://taskwarrior.org/wiki/taskwarrior/About |date=April 8, 2010 }}</ref> in the Todo.txt applications popularized by [[Gina Trapani]].<ref>[http://todotxt.com/ Todo.txt] Future-proof task tracking in a file you control</ref>
With ''Timewarrior,'' the authors offer an accompanying tool to track time spent on projects.<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/news/news.20160620.html</ref> Configuration allows e. g. to define recurring breaks such as lunch time.<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/docs/timewarrior/workweek.html</ref> The documention notes that "Timewarrior focusses on accurately recording time already spent, whereas Taskwarrior looks forward to work that is not yet done."<ref>http://taskwarrior.org/docs/timewarrior/backdated.html</ref>
==Availability== Taskwarrior's source code is freely available and can be compiled and run on a variety of architectures and operating systems, or installed using binaries obtained with common package management tools: ([[Advanced Packaging Tool|apt]], [[Fink]], [[Yellowdog Updater, Modified|yum]], [[DNF (software)|dnf]], pkgng, pkg_add, etc.)<ref>[http://tasktools.org/gitweb/?p=task.git;a=blob;f=NEWS;h=6f87bea2840e2f2f1948125e37a4e1f3091546a4;hb=2.0.0 Task 2.0.0 NEWS file]</ref>
==Typical Workflow== Taskwarrior comprises three main commands: ''add'', ''list'', and ''done.'' All other functionality – recurrences, tags, priorities, etc. – are optional.
===Adding a task=== <source lang="console"> $ task add Pick up keys to the new apartment Created task 1. </source> ===Listing Tasks=== <source lang="console"> $ task list ID Project Pri Due Active Age Description 1 4 secs Pick up keys to the new apartment 1 task </source>
===Marking a task as completed=== <source lang="console"> $ task 1 done Completed 1 'Pick up keys to the new apartment'. Marked 1 task as done. </source> ===Creating a task with due dates, recurrences, and tags=== <source lang="console"> $ task add Mow the lawn project:Lawnwork due:tomorrow recur:biweekly +home Created task 1. </source>
==Syncing== When used in conjunction with Taskserver, can sync tasks into the cloud, and indirectly with other clients/devices.
==Accolades== * Issue 124 of the UK ''[[Linux Format]]'' magazine (November 2009) featured Taskwarrior in its Hot Picks section.<ref>http://www.linuxformat.com/archives?issue=124</ref> * [[RadioTux]] Talk #137 (July 2011, German) chose Taskwarrior as Hot Pick<ref>http://blog.radiotux.de/2011/07/14/talk-137-daumenkino-3-schneller/</ref> * [[FLOSS Weekly]] dedicated episode 175 (July 2011) to Taskwarrior<ref>[http://www.twit.tv/floss175 FLOSS Weekly 175], TWiT.TV</ref> * ''[[Linux Voice]]'' featured a tutorial on Taskwarrior<ref name="LinuxVoice">{{cite journal|last1=Saunders|first1=Mike|title=FOSSpicks: Taskwarrior 2.3.0|journal=Linux Voice|date=September 2014|issue=6|page=69|url=http://www.linuxvoice.com/issues/006/foss6.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170909053120/http://www.linuxvoice.com/issues/006/foss6.pdf |archivedate=2017-09-09 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Free software}} * [[Comparison of time-tracking software]] * [[Getting Things Done]] * [[Time management]] * [[Task management]] * [[Org-mode]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official|https://taskwarrior.org}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Taskwarrior}} [[Category:Administrative software]] [[Category:Time-tracking software]] [[Category:Task management software]] [[Category:Free task management software]] [[Category:Free personal information managers]] [[Category:Cross-platform free software]] [[Category:Free calendaring software]] [[Category:Software using the MIT license]] [[Category:Command-line software]]

revision.comment: link [[channel stuffing]] using [[:en:User:Edward/Find link|Find link]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Tomo Razmilovic.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Razmilovic, as shown on a U.S. Postal Inspection Service wanted poster. Photo taken 1994.]] '''Tomo Razmilovic''' (born 31 May 1942) is a [[Croatia]]n-born businessman, formerly the [[chief executive officer]] of [[Long Island, New York]]-based [[Symbol Technologies]]. He is the suspected mastermind of a massive [[accounting scandal|accounting fraud]] that ultimately cost the company its independence. Currently, the [[United States Government]] considers him a [[fugitive]], with the [[United States Postal Inspection Service]] offering a $100,000 reward for information leading to his arrest and conviction.<ref name=usps-poster>{{cite web|title=Wanted Poster of Tomo Razmilovic|url=https://postalinspectors.uspis.gov/radDocs/wanted/razmilov.htm|accessdate=17 February 2012}}</ref>
Born in [[Split, Croatia]], Razmilovic studied [[electrical engineering]] at the [[University of Zagreb]] and management at the Hammond Institute in [[Sweden]].<ref name=nyt-longisland>{{cite news|last=Tagliaferro|first=Linda|title=Long Island Q&A: Tomo Razmilovic, Moving From Bar Codes to Advances in Communications|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/19/nyregion/long-island-q-tomo-razmilovic-moving-bar-codes-advances-communications.html?src=pm|accessdate=1 March 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=19 May 1996}}</ref> He obtained Swedish [[citizenship]] in 1971.<ref name=ceoannouncement>[http://www.symbol.com/news/pressreleases/pr_finanstock_ceo.html Press release from Symbol] announcing appointment as CEO</ref>
Razmilovic joined Symbol in 1989 as Senior Vice President of International Operations, becoming head of Worldwide Sales and Service in 1993 and president and [[chief operating officer]] in 1995. He succeeded founder [[Jerome Swartz]] as CEO in 2000. Previously, he had been president of [[International Computers Limited]], a British computer manufacturer, and president and CEO of Cominvest, a [[Economy of Sweden|Swedish]] computer company.<ref name=ceoannouncement/> He abruptly retired in 2002 in the midst of a [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] inquiry into its accounting practices.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/28/nyregion/li-work-at-symbol-changes-at-top-ahd-hopes-for-revival.html|title=At Symbol, Changes At Top and Hopes for Revival|last=Strugatch|first=Warren|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2002-07-28}}</ref>
On May 28, 2004, an [[arrest warrant]] for Razmilovic was issued by the [[United States District Court]] in [[Brooklyn]]. According to the United States Postal Inspection Service, he is wanted for orchestrating a massive accounting fraud that cost investors more than $200 million. <ref name=newsday-fugitive>{{cite web|last=Harrington|first=Mark|title=Fugitive ex-CEO faces $90M civil penalty |url=http://www.newsday.com/business/fugitive-ex-ceo-faces-90m-civil-penalty-1.3228303|work=Newsday|accessdate=17 February 2012}}</ref> He was formally indicted on June 3, along with seven other former Symbol executives. According to investigators, Razmilovic was the mastermind behind a wide-ranging scheme to inflate the company's sales and profits. It included several types of fraud, such as [[channel stuffing]] (booking sales to wholesalers and distributors as final sales to customers), candy deals (selling products to distributors with no matching customer orders and then buying the products back), use of tango sheets (records of how much revenues had to be inflated to match quarterly targets) and use of cookie jar reserves (declaring nonrecurring expenses that far exceeded likely expenses). On the same day, Razmilovic and 10 other executives were sued by the SEC for the fraud.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/04/business/ex-executives-at-symbol-are-indicted.htm|title=Ex-Executives at Symbol Are Indicted|last=Lohr|first=Steve|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2004-06-04}}</ref> Eventually, four executives pleaded guilty, and seven executives settled SEC charges against them. Several of those who pleaded guilty stated under oath that Razmilovic was the mastermind of the fraud.<ref name=apologydemand/> After the fraud came to light, it was revealed that Razmilovic had been forced out at Cominvest due to accounting irregularities.<ref name=WaitingOut>{{cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-07-04/business/0407030278_1_tomo-razmilovic-swedish-charges|title=Ex-Symbol CEO waiting out charges in Sweden|last=Harrington|first=John|publisher=[[Newsday]]|date=2004-07-04}}</ref>
Symbol learned of the fraud in the summer of 2002 via an internal investigation, and cooperated with authorities. In late 2002, it restated almost four years worth of earnings from 1998 to 2001, in the process erasing $234 million in revenue and $325 million in net income. It also paid $37 million to settle the SEC charges and $138 million to settle numerous shareholder suits.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/06/21/business/technology-day-2-i-learn-the-books-are-cooked.html|title=Technology, Day 2: I Learn the Books Are Cooked|last=Lohr|first=Steve|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=2013-06-21}}</ref><ref>[https://www.sec.gov/litigation/litreleases/lr18734.htm SEC suit against Symbol]</ref><ref name=SECorder>[http://www.secactions.com/sec-obtains-62-6-million-judgement-against-former-ceo/ SEC release announcing penalties against Razmilovic]</ref> The company never recovered, and was ultimately forced to merge with [[Motorola]] in 2007.<ref name=AmericanGreed>{{cite video |people= |date=2013 |title=[[American Greed|American Greed: The Fugitives]]: Diamonds Aren't Forever |url= |format= |medium=Television Production |publisher=[[CNBC]] |location=[[United States]] |accessdate= |time= |quote= }}</ref>
Razmilovic was not heard from again until 2004, when [[WNBC]] in [[New York City]] and [[Newsday]], the main newspaper on [[Long Island]], found him living in a small town in Sweden.<ref name=apologydemand>{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Tomo-Razmilovic-Fugitive-Millionaire-Sweden-CEO-Symbol-Technologies-Long-Island-232921331.html|title=Fugitive Long Island CEO Accused of $200 Million Fraud Wants Apology |last=Dienst|first=Jonathan|publisher=[[WNBC]]|date=2013-11-21}}</ref><ref name=WaitingOut/> He had fled there citing claims that he would not be able to get a fair trial in the United States.<ref name=newsday-fugitive/> In 2008, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine named Razmilovic one of the "World's Most Wanted White-Collar Fugitives".<ref name="forbes">{{cite web|last=Vardi|first=Nathan|title=The World's Most Wanted White-Collar Fugutives |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/08/27/legal-crime-fbi-biz-cz_nv_0827fugitives.html|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=17 February 2012 |author2=Asher Hawkins }}</ref>
The SEC won a [[default judgement]] against Razmilovic in 2009. In 2011, federal judge [[Sandra J. Feuerstein]] ordered Razmilovic to [[disgorgement (law)|disgorge]] $41.7 million in illegal profits and pay a $20.8 million civil penalty. With interest, the penalty could add up to as much as $47 million. He is also banned from ever serving as an officer or director of a public company again.<ref name=newsday-fugitive/><ref name=SECorder/> On January 17, 2014, federal prosecutors on Long Island filed a civil suit seeking the forfeiture of $12 million in illegal profits that they believe Razmilovic has hidden in a [[Credit Suisse]] account.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/suffolk/feds-seek-12m-from-fugitive-li-tech-exec-1.6823709|title=Feds seek $12M from fugitive LI tech exec|last=Riley|first=John|publisher=[[Newsday]]|date=2014-01-18}}</ref>
Razmilovic maintains that he is innocent, and in a 2013 interview with WNBC and [[CNBC]] went as far as to demand an apology from investigators and media covering the story. He has stated that he has no intention of returning to the United States to face the charges against him. Sweden will not give up Razmilovic for [[extradition]] because it does not turn over suspected white-collar criminals to a country not located in the [[European Union]].<ref name=apologydemand/>
The accounting fraud was profiled by CNBC's ''[[American Greed|American Greed: The Fugitives]]'' in 2013.<ref name=AmericanGreed/>
== Notes == <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Razmilovic, Tomo}} [[Category:1942 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Fugitive financiers]] [[Category:People from Split, Croatia]] [[Category:American white-collar criminals]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted by the United States]] [[Category:Fugitives wanted on fraud charges]] [[Category:Swedish people of Serbian descent]] [[Category:International Computers Limited people]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]] [[Category:Chief operating officers]]

page.title: Types of legal entities in Russia

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Business law]]; added [[Category:Russian business law]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=July 2014}}
*IP (Индивидуальный предприниматель) – Russian "Individual entrepreneur" *OOO (Общество с ограниченной ответственностью, ООО) – Russian "Limited liability company" LLC is set up by one or several persons (legal entities and/or individuals), its charter capital is divided into participatory shares, and LLC participants are not liable for company’s obligations and bear the risk of losses to the extent of the contributions made by them. The number of shareholders may not exceed 50.<ref>[http://www.gtrus.com/main.php?year=&g_search=&chapter=public&page=gt_business «Legal regulation of foreign investments, Grant Thornton] // Doing Business in Russia, p.11, 04.2012</ref> *ZAO (Закрытое акционерное общество, ЗАО) – Russian "Private joint-stock company" In a PrivJSC shares are distributed only among its founders or another predetermined group of persons. A closed company has the right to conduct a closed subscription to its shares, while the shareholders of a closed company have a pre-emptive right to purchase shares sold by other company shareholders. The number of company’s shareholders should not exceed 50.<ref name="gtrus.com">[http://www.gtrus.com/main.php?year=&g_search=&chapter=public&page=gt_business «Legal regulation of foreign investments, Grant Thornton] // Doing Business in Russia, p.13, 04.2012</ref> *OAO (Открытое акционерное общество, ОАО) – Russian "Public joint-stock company" An open company has the right to conduct open subscription to its shares – among an unlimited group of persons and closed subscription (a limited predetermined group of persons), if the opportunity to conduct a closed subscription is not limited by company’s charter or legal acts. Shareholders do not have a pre-emptive right to purchase shares sold by other shareholders of the company. The number of shareholders is unlimited.<ref name="gtrus.com"/> *ANO (Автономная некоммерческая организация, АНО) – Russian "Autonomous non-profit organization" *GP or GUP (Государственное унитарное предприятие, ГП or ГУП) – Russian "[[Unitary enterprise|Unitary state enterprise]]" *Фонд – Russian "[[Collective investment scheme|Fund]]" *PK (Производственный кооператив, ПK) – Russian "Production Cooperative" *PP (Политическая партия, ПП) – Russian "Political party"
==References== <references /> <!--- After listing your sources please cite them using inline citations and place them after the information they cite. Please see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. ---> * * * *
<!--- STOP! Be warned that by using this process instead of Articles for Creation, this article is subject to scrutiny. As an article in "mainspace", it will be DELETED if there are problems, not just declined. If you wish to use AfC, please return to the Wizard and continue from there. --->

revision.comment: minor fixes, replaced: [[London]] → London, - → – using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Sir William Forbes, 1st of Callendar | image = Sirwilliamforbes.jpg | imagesize = 175 px | caption = Portrait by [[Raeburn]] – hangs in [[Callendar House]] | birth_date = 1756 | birth_place = [[Aberdeen]], [[Aberdeenshire]] | death_date = 1823 | death_place = [[Falkirk]], [[Scotland]] | occupation = Landowner | salary = | networth = c. £500,000 (c.$1 billion today) | spouse = Margaret McAdam, Agnes Chalmers | children = William, John, Katherine, Jessie, Agnes | website = }} [[File:William Forbes of Callendar by Sir Henry Raeburn, SNPG.JPG|thumb|William Forbes of Callendar by Sir [[Henry Raeburn]] (detail) 1798]] '''Sir William Forbes of Callendar''' (1756–1823) was a prosperous [[copper]]smith and landowner who lived in [[Callendar House]] in [[Falkirk]], [[Scotland]].
==Biography== Forbes was a self-made man. The son of an [[Aberdeen]] merchant, he began work as a coppersmith and won a government contract to sheath ships' [[Hull (watercraft)|hull]]s in copper. With the fortune he made (equivalent to over [[USD|$]]1 billion in today's terms), he purchased the estates of Callendar and [[Linlithgow]] near Falkirk, which had been forfeited by the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] [[Earl of Linlithgow]] after the [[1715 Jacobite rising]]. He bought the estates at auction and is said to have astounded bystanders by producing a banknote for £100,000, specially printed for the occasion, at the age of just 40. At the time he was the greatest landowner in the county, with some of the largest collected lands in [[Scotland]]. He was not popular with local people, but nevertheless his family retained great influence over the area for two centuries.
Wishing to set himself up as a 'landed gentleman', William purchased further vast estates in [[Ayrshire]], Earlstoun, [[Kirkcudbrightshire]] and [[Dumfriesshire]]. He spent ten years making improvements to Callendar House, dividing his time between the house and London. He gave orders for the complete renovation and refurnishing of the entire house, adding a new wing and ripping out old rooms. He added the various turrets and exterior decoration which give the house its chateau-like appearance today. Although William preferred the newest fashion (and purchased the best furniture and household goods from makers in London and [[Edinburgh]]) he did not spend money recklessly, ordering the new servants' wing to be furnished 'in the cheapest way'.
His first wife was Margaret McAdam, daughter of John McAdam of [[Craigengillan]]. She did not keep well and was sent to Madeira for her health's sake. There she died, at the early age of 28, in March 1793. Her gravestone, English marble, sent from London, can be seen in the English Cemetery, Funchal. Forbes remarried in 1806 Agnes Chalmers, daughter of John Chalmers of Old Machar in Aberdeen. This union produced two sons and three daughters. The Forbes household settled down after William's marriage and he began to spend more time in Callendar House and give his brother David greater control of the business in London.
In 1794, aged 51, he retired to become a full-time landowner, rejecting the idea of employing a factor trained in the needs of estate management and elected to manage the {{convert|8000|acre|km2|adj=on}} estates himself. His first son William, 2nd of Callendar, went on to become [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Stirlingshire (UK Parliament constituency)|Stirlingshire]].
Forbes' descendants sold Callendar House in the 1960s and are listed in ''[[Burke's Landed Gentry]]''.
==References== *[http://www.falkirk-wheel.com/millennium-makers/william-forbes-of-callendar-5.html Biography]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Forbes, Sir William}} [[Category:1756 births]] [[Category:1823 deaths]] [[Category:Scottish knights]] [[Category:Scottish coppersmiths]] [[Category:People from Aberdeen]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]] [[Category:People associated with Falkirk (council area)]] [[Category:Scottish landowners]]

{{Infobox award | Women's Image Award = | subheader = <!-- or | current_awards = --> | image = Win logo NO DATE.jpg | image_size = <!-- or | image_upright = --> | alt = | caption = | description = Promoting outstanding media (created by both men & women), The Women's Image Awards advance the value of women and girls. | sponsor = | date = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location = <!-- or | venue = or | site = --> | country = [[United States]] | presenter = | host = <!-- or | hosts = --> | former name = The WIN Awards | preshow_host = | acts = | reward = | year = | year2 = | holder_label = | holder = <!-- or | winner = or | winners = --> | most_awards = <!-- or | most_wins = --> | most_nominations = | award1_type = | award1_winner = | award2_type = | award2_winner = | award3_type = | award3_winner = | award4_type = | award4_winner = | award5_type = | award5_winner = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | network = <!-- or | network_list = --> | runtime = | viewership = <!-- or | ratings = --> | producer = Women's Image Network / Phyllis Stuart | director = | image2 = | image2size = <!-- or | image_upright2 --> | alt2 = | caption2 = | precedence_label = | individual = | higher = | same = | lower = | related = | previous = | main = | next = }}
'''Women's Image Network''' (WIN), was founded in 1993 to promote gender parity by [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/bert-stern-original-mad-man-432680 filmmaker, Phyllis Stuart]. This company became successful from the ongoing support, advice and assistance provided by seasoned entertainment professionals including [[Sherry Lansing]] and [[Arthur Hiller]], just two of the illustrious WIN founding advisory board members.
The charity Women's Image Network produces The Women's Image Awards because to the extent that women's voices remain silent everyone is robbed of their contribution. This growing awards show is now produced during the Hollywood awards season to promote deserving media and drive attention to feature films also contending for Golden Globe and Academy Awards.<ref name="articles.latimes.com">{{Cite news|title = WIN Symposium and Awards Ceremony Set|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1993-07-22/entertainment/ca-15675_1_awards-ceremony|newspaper = Los Angeles Times|date = 1993-07-22|access-date = 2015-12-08|issn = 0458-3035}}</ref>
Selecting only media submitted from film studios and television networks, their jury adjudicates and nominates work which either tells a dimensional female character's story or nominates work that is produced, written or directed by a woman. In this way, these awards celebrate both male and female artists whose film and television work also increases the value of women and girls.
In addition to awarding nominated film and television work, WIN also honors deserving individuals including: [[Lauren Bacall]], [[Senator Barbara Boxer]], [[Lily Tomlin]], [[Cecilia DeMille Presley]], [[Abigail Disney]], Ambassador [[Swanee Hunt]], [[Suzanne Roberts]], [[Maria Arena Bell]], [[Diane Ladd]], [[Jane Campion]], [[Anne Archer]], [[Carrie Fisher]] and [[Irena Medavoy]], among others.<ref>https://www.broadwayworld.com/los-angeles/article/WIN-Honors-Elizabeth-Taylor-and-Suzanne-Fleisher-Roberts-20101206</ref><ref>http://www.ireachcontent.com/news-releases/the-win-awards-2013--film--television-nominees--honorees-rosalind-jarrett-sepulveda-cecilia-demille-presley--ambassador-swanee-hunt-233078341.html</ref>
The night of her tribute, [[Lauren Bacall]], an iconic cinema legend said she was [http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/DAILY-NEWS-LAUREN.jpg moved to tears by her tribute] by the heartfelt remarks made [http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/variety-army-archerd.jpg her three children]., ([[Sam Robards]], [[Leslie Bogart]], [[Sam Bogart]]).
==The WIN Awards 1993== In 1993, WIN held its first awards ceremony honoring [[Tichi Wilkerson Kassel]] with a Lifetime Achievement Award. Tichi was the first female publisher of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' and co-founder of [[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards|Women In Film]]. Her friend [[Charles Champlin]] (a former ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' arts editor and film critic) presented her award. Film producer [[Laura Ziskin]], (''[[Spider-Man (2002 film)|Spider-Man]]'') (who also founded [[Stand Up to Cancer]] before she succumbed to the disease at age 61), was honored that same year and her former boss, producer [[Jon Peters]] presented her Woman of The Year tribute.<ref name="articles.latimes.com">{{Cite news|title = WIN Symposium and Awards Ceremony Set|url = http://articles.latimes.com/1993-07-22/entertainment/ca-15675_1_awards-ceremony|newspaper = Los Angeles Times|date = 1993-07-22|access-date = 2015-12-08|issn = 0458-3035}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Producer Laura Ziskin dies at 61|url = https://variety.com/2011/film/news/producer-laura-ziskin-dies-at-61-1118038459/|website = Variety|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/LA-WOMEN'S-IMAGE.jpg|title = LA WOMEN'S IMAGE|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Ziskin|first = Laura}}</ref><ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1993-07-22/entertainment/ca-15675_1_awards-ceremony WIN Symposium and Awards Ceremony Set July 22, 1993 Los Angeles Times]</ref>
==The WIN Awards 1994== In 1994, for WIN, producer [http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/458451/50-Years-of-Funny-Females/ Phyllis Stuart] [http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/tv-guide.jpg created and Executive Produced the ABC Primetime Special] [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0283341/?ref_=fn_al_tt_1 "Fifty Years of Funny Females"] starring [[John Ritter]], [[Annie Potts]], [[Paula Poundstone]], [[Debbie Allen]] and [[Pam Stone]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = 50 Years of Funny Females {{!}} Full Cast and Credits {{!}} 1994|url = http://www.hollywood.com/tv/50-years-of-funny-females-59485635/credits/|website = Hollywood.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> This clip show aired twice on ABC and again on Lifetime Television.
==The WIN Awards 1999==
For four years, The WIN Awards coincided with The WIN Femme Film Festival created to support emerging and/or first-time filmmakers.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Calls For Entries|url = http://www.safilm.org.za/interviews/interview.php?uid=183|website = www.safilm.org.za|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://lists.csbs.utah.edu/pipermail/marxism/2000-December/046453.html|title = [floridaleft] [culture] WinFemme Film Festival Presents Finely Wrought Tales (fwd)|date = 2000-12-12|accessdate = 2015-12-08|first = Michael|last = Hoover}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Shona Auerbach|url = http://www.shonaauerbach.com/|website = Shona Auerbach|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Voices Unveiled: Turkish Women Who Dare|url = http://www.voicesunveiled.com/html/filmakers.html|website = www.voicesunveiled.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Pictures From The WinFemme Film Festival And The WIN Awards|url = http://imagecollect.com/events/the-winfemme-film-festival-and-the-win-awards-photos-732|website = imagecollect.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> [https://www.awn.com/news/winfemme-film-festival-wants-womens-stories WinFemme Film Festival Wants Women's Stories]
[http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/chicago-tribune.jpg The WIN Femme Film Festival] programmed independently produced short films, documentary feature films and full length feature films which told a woman's story, had a female protagonist, but which were created either by male or female artists).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Tilt Cinema & Faust Films|url = http://tiltcinema.com/film-tv/drama/three-lives-of-kate/|website = Tilt Cinema & Faust Films|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/VARIETY-YEAR-1.jpg|title = Par Hosts Femme Film Festival|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Completed Projects|url = http://robinmurphyproductions.com/completed-films/|website = Robin Murphy Productions|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> [http://depositphotos.com/17951543/stock-photo-france-nuyen.html Best] documentary went to [[Paolo di Florio]] for her film, ''[[Speaking in Strings|Speaking In Strings]].''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Paola di Florio Biography - - Cinedigm Entertainment|url = http://www.newvideo.com/filmmakers/paola-di-florio-biography/|website = www.newvideo.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> WIN created this festival to help filmmakers find distribution,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Films Media Group - If I Could: Breaking the Vicious Cycle of Child Abuse-Educator's Edition|url = http://www.films.com/ecTitleDetail.aspx?TitleID=13058|website = www.films.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = BRIAN TO Productions {{!}} Celebrity & Fashion Photographer in Los Angeles|url = http://www.briantoproductions.com/|website = www.briantoproductions.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> get agents and win other awards;<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Writers Place|url = http://www.thewritersplace.org/cofounders.shtml|website = www.thewritersplace.org|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> ''[[Speaking in Strings|Speaking In Strings]]'' went on to win an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nomination. Director [[John Putch]] (son of [[Jean Stapleton]]) won best feature with ''[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0163889/?ref_=nm_flmg_dr_40 Valerie Flake]'' starring [http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film/susan-traylor-the-casserole-club/ Susan Traylor] (wife of [[Bob Dylan]]'s son director, [[Jesse Dylan]]) who also garnered a Spirit Award for best actress.<ref>{{Cite web|title = NEWSWIRE|url = http://www.backstage.com/news/newswire_6/|website = Backstage.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = WINFEMME we Want Scripts & Films TELLING WOMEN'S STORIES {{!}} Filmmaker.com|url = http://www.filmmaker.com/node/5650|website = www.filmmaker.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>
==The WIN Awards 2000==
[http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/variety-army-archerd.jpg Actress Lauren Bacall] accepted WIN's first Living Legend tribute. That night New Zealand film director, [[Jane Campion]] was also honored and her ''Piano'' film star [[Sam Neill]] accepted her tribute on her behalf.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Actor Sam Neill attends WinFemme Film Festival Gala Honoring Lauren...|url = http://www.gettyimages.ch/detail/nachrichtenfoto/actor-sam-neill-attends-winfemme-film-festival-gala-nachrichtenfoto/155503636|website = Getty Images|accessdate = 2015-12-08|language = de}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Actor Sam Neill and actress Lauren Bacall attend WinFemme Film...|url = http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/actor-sam-neill-and-actress-lauren-bacall-attend-winfemme-news-photo/155503625|website = Getty Images|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>

==The WIN Awards 2002== Actress [[Lily Tomlin]] was honored as a Lifetime Achievement honoree. In lieu of a tribute video, Tomlin was applauded with 'Lily Love Letters' sent from famous friends and serenaded by Director, [[David O. Russell]]. <nowiki></nowiki> [[Ruth Buzzi]] ''[[Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In|Laugh In]]'', presented.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Lily Tomlin|url = https://m.imdb.com/name/nm0005499/trivia|website = IMDb|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>
Presenters included: [[Laraine Newman]], [[Kathy Najimy]], [[Ruth Buzzi]], [[Doris Roberts]], [[Melissa Joan Hart]], [[Anne-Marie Johnson]], [[Arthur Hiller]], [[Dava Savel]], [[Sally Kirkland]] and [[Alex Ben Block]].

''The WIN Awards'' were part of the closing night of the final WinFemme Film Festival. The three filmmaker Audience Award winners were winners were: (Feature Film), "Controlled Chaos", director, [[Azita Zendel]], (Documentary Feature), ''Searching For Paradise'', director, [[Binnur Karaevli]] and (Short Film), ''Katherine'', director, [[Mary Louise Stoughton]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://imagecollect.com/picture/lily-tomlin-film-school-photo-29016/the-winfemme-film-festival-and-the-win-awards|title=Photos and Pictures - Lily Tomlin at the WinFemme Film Festival, at The Los Angeles Film School, Hollywood, CA 09-09-02|website=imagecollect.com|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref>
==The WIN Awards 2003==
Hosted by [[Will Sasso]] and [[Sara Rue]]. Producer [[Lauren Shuler Donner]] received a Lifetime Achievement Award from presenter. [[Rachel Weisz]]. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aCii800MCwE Rachel Weisz presents to Lauren Shuler Donner at The WIN Awards 2003.]
Held at the historic Culver City Studios, [http://www.thewinawards.com/images/2004_press/daily-variety.jpg Director Vicky Jensen [[Shrek] was honored] with WIN's first Kiera Chaplin Limelight directing award.<ref name="Kim Possible Wins WIN Awards">{{Cite web|title = Kim Possible Wins WIN Awards|url = http://www.animationmagazine.net/events/kim-possible-wins-win-awards/|website = Animation Magazine|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> British model and actress [[Kiera Chaplin]] is the granddaughter of film legend [[Charlie Chaplin]] and great-grand daughter of playwright [[Eugene O'Neill|Eugene O’Neill]].
Presenters and guests included [[Carrie Fisher]], [[Richard Donner]], [[Bonnie Palef]], [[Peter Guber]], [[Yeardley Smith]], [[Melissa Joan Hart]], [[Brittany Snow]], [[Holliston Coleman]], [[Al Jean]], [[Sarah Ramos]], [[Sean Patrick Thomas]], [[Jane Anderson]], [[Valarie Pettiford]], [[Dayna Devon]], [[Neal McDonough]], [[Charlie Robinson (actor)|Charlie Robinson]] and [[Suzanne Sena]].

==The WIN Awards 2005==
[[Kathy Griffin]] Hosted The WIN Awards 2005. [[Christine Lahti]], [[Andrea Parker]], [[Amy Davidson]], [[Lainie Kazan]], [[Gurinder Chadha]], [[Dan Wieden]], [[Lu Chekowsky]], [[Maureen Shirreff]], [[Jennifer Hall]], [[Lindsay Crouse]] and [[Danielle Panabaker]] were among the presenters, and its nominated actors, directors, writers and producers celebrated for having created outstanding work that dispelled stereotypes of women.
[[Gurinder Chadha]] picked up the Chaplin Limelight Award for directing presented by [[Charlie Chaplin|Charlie Chaplan]]'s granddaughter [[Kiera Chaplin]] for whom this award was created. The animated series Kim Possible, and [[Kathy Najimy]] also won this same award two years later.<ref name="Kim Possible Wins WIN Awards" /><ref>{{Cite web|title = The WIN Awards 2005 To Honor British Filmmaker, Gurinder Chadha|url = http://pressbox.co.uk/Arts/The_WIN_Awards_2005_To_Honor_British_Filmmaker_Gurinder_Chadha_29857.html|website = pressbox.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>

==The WIN Awards 2007==
Held at The Pacific Design Center, [[Diane Ladd]] accepted her Lifetime Achievement Award. [[Frances Fisher]] presented. * [[Angelina Jolie]] accepted (via a pre-taped speech) best actress in a feature film award for [[A Mighty Heart (film)]]. * ''[[Army Wives]]'' star, [[Sally Pressman]] and [[Tracee Ellis Ross]] co-hosted. * Honorees [[Janet Kestin]] and [[Nancy Vonk]], Co-Chief Creatives, Ogilvy-Toronto accepted an inaugural Harriett Abbott Advertising Award. * Though awards for male actors are no longer given, [[Seth Rogen]] won a best actor award for [[Knocked Up]]. Rogen also picked up a trophy on behalf of his ''[[Knocked Up]]'' film producer, [[Shauna Robertson]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Women's Image Network 2007|url = http://thewinawards.com/2007winners.html|website = thewinawards.com|accessdate = 2015-12-26}}</ref> [[Alec Baldwin]] won for ''[[30 Rock]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jewelsandpinstripes.com/events_winawards.htm|title=Events_Specialty Bags|website=www.jewelsandpinstripes.com|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref><nowiki/> * <u>'''The WIN Awards 2007 Winners:'''</u> * '''Made For Television Movie / Mini-Series''' ''A Girl Like Me: The Gwen Araujo Story'' * '''Actress Made For Television Movie / Mini-Series''' [[Andrea Bowen]] ''Girl Posi+ive'' * '''Actor Made For Television Movie / Mini-Series''' [[Wendell Pierce]] ''Life Support'' * '''Comedy Series''' ''Ugly Betty'' "I’m Coming Out" * '''Actress Comedy Series''' [[Ashley Jensen]] ''Extras'' * '''Actor Comedy Series''' [[Alec Baldwin]] ''30 Rock'' “Hardball” * '''Documentary Film''' ''Thin'' * '''Film or Show Produced by a Woman''' [[Shauna Robertson]] ''Knocked Up'' * '''Film or Show Directed by a Woman''' [[Rory Kennedy]] ''Ghosts of Abu Ghraib'' * '''Actress Animation Series''' [[Kathy Najimy]] ''King Of The Hill'' * '''Reality Series''' ''Kimora: Life In The Fab Lane'' * '''Drama Series''' ''Army Wives'' “A Tribe Is Born” * '''Actress Drama Series''' [[Connie Britton]] ''Friday Night Lights'' * '''Actor Drama Series''' [[Taylor Kitsch]] ''Friday Night Lights'' * '''Actress Feature Film''' [[Angelina Jolie]] ''A Mighty Heart'' * '''Actor Feature Film''' [[Seth Rogen]] ''Knocked Up'' * '''Feature Film''' ''A Mighty Heart''

==The WIN Awards 2009==

==The WIN Awards 2010==
This was a big awards show year for The WIN awards as WIN created two new Lifetime Achievement awards. These recipients were Suzanne Roberts and Dame Elizabeth Taylor. [[Elizabeth Taylor]] friend [[Mickey Rooney]] accepted this "Living Legend" award to celebrate Taylor's lifetime work in Hollywood and her charity work advancing HIV/AIDS activism.<ref name="hollyrep">{{cite news|title = Elizabeth Taylor, Jennifer Aniston, Jane Lynch to be Honored by Women’s Image Network|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/womens-image-network-honor-elizabeth-56786|accessdate = 17 January 2011|newspaper = The Hollywood Reporter|date = 6 December 2010}}</ref><ref name="Propst">{{cite web|last=Propst|first=Andy|title=Glee, Claire Danes, Sally Hawkins, Jane Lynch, Susan Sarandon, Maggie Smith et al. Receive WIN Nominations|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/12-2010/glee-claire-danes-sally-hawkins-jane-lynch-susan-s_32562.html|publisher=TheaterMania|date= 7 December 2010|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Elizabeth Taylor to be Honored by Women's Network|url = http://www.backstage.com/news/elizabeth-taylor-to-be-honored-by-womens-network/|website = Backstage.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>
The 2010 WIN Awards also honored Suzanne Roberts for her many career achievements. Her sons, Douglas Roberts and [[Brian L. Roberts]], (Chairman of Comcast and NBC/Universal) and her husband, Ralph J. Roberts presented to Mrs. Roberts. (http://www.broadwayworld.com/los-angeles/article/win-honors-elizabeth-taylor-and-suzanne-fleisher-roberts-20101206) http://www.suzanne.tv/about-suzanne.aspx.
Produced at The Broad Stage, [[Wendy Liebman]] hosted.
[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]], [[Claire Danes]], [[Sally Hawkins]], [[Jennifer Aniston]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Average Socialite™: 16th Annual Women's Image Awards, LA|url = http://www.averagesocialite.com/2014/12/16th-annual-womens-image-awards-mar-2.html|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>[[Diane Lane]], [[Joey King]], [[Selena Gomez]], [[Jane Lynch]], [[Susan Sarandon]] and [[Maggie Smith]] were among the many WIN Awards nominees.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Glee, Claire Danes, Sally Hawkins, Jane Lynch, Susan Sarandon, Maggie Smith et al. Receive WIN Nominations|url = http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/12-2010/glee-claire-danes-sally-hawkins-jane-lynch-susan-s_32562.html|website = TheaterMania.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>
Show presenters included: [[Carl Reiner]], [[Lea Thompson]], [[AJ Michalka]], [[John Savage (actor)]], [[Sean Young]], [[Sara Rue]], [[Kahi Lee]], and [[Sally Kirkland]]. * '''<u>HONOREES</u>''' [[Elizabeth Taylor]]: Living Legend Honoree and presenter, [[Mickey Rooney]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/los-angeles/article/WIN-Honors-Elizabeth-Taylor-and-Suzanne-Fleisher-Roberts-20101206|title=WIN Honors Elizabeth Taylor and Suzanne Fleisher Roberts|last=Desk|first=BWW News|website=BroadwayWorld.com|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> In addition, [[Suzanne Roberts]], wife of Ralph Roberts (owner of [[Comcast]]), mother to [[Brian L. Roberts]], presented her with WIN's Lifetime Achievement award for her long career of patronage of the arts.<ref name="Klein">{{cite news|last=Klein|first=Michael|title=Inqlings: Suzanne Roberts a WIN-ner|url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-01-18/news/27034653_1_inauguration-committee-mozart-opener|accessdate=8 October 2012|newspaper=philly.com|date=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=WIN Honors Elizabeth Taylor and Suzanne Fleisher roberts|url=http://losangeles.broadwayworld.com/article/WIN_Honors_Elizabeth_Taylor_and_Suzanne_Fleisher_Roberts_20101206|date = 6 December 2010|publisher=Broadway World|accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Inqlings: Suzanne Roberts a WIN-ner|url = http://articles.philly.com/2011-01-18/news/27034653_1_inauguration-committee-mozart-opener|website = philly-archives|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthbistro.lifescript.com/2011/01/19/women-image-network-win-awards-bring-out-women-and-men-in-force/|title='Women Image Network (WIN) Awards' Bring Out Women and Men in Force|last=19|first=Mari Cartel on January|last2=2011|website=Lifescript Health Bistro|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * "I am honored to be recognized by the Women's Image Network tonight. I applaud the work of [https://www.huffingtonpost.com/author/phyllis-stuart Phyllis Stuart] in promoting gender parity and fostering creative opportunity throughout our industry. I have been fortunate throughout my career, but never more so than when I was able to use my fame to raise funds and awareness for the HIV/AIDS crisis, work which remains my singular focus. I am touched to be included among WIN's honorees and so gratified to know my efforts are appreciated. Although I am not able to join you for tonight's awards ceremony, please know I am with you in spirit. Each and every one of you here tonight is making a generous contribution to our community. Through your courage to act and your willingness to share, you provide a vital, effective link for women and girls throughout our industry. I am grateful for this honor, and thank you from the bottom of my heart. Sincerely, [[Elizabeth Taylor]]"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thewinawards.com/NEWS_Archives.html|title=Women's Image Network|website=www.thewinawards.com|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.starzlife.com/20101207/elizabeth-taylor-to-be-honored-for-charity-work/|title=Elizabeth Taylor To Be Honored For Charity Work - StarzLife|website=StarzLife|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref>

[[Grammy Award|Grammy]] winner, [[David Foster]] and [[Ruben Studdard]], performed at The WIN Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title = David Foster and Ruben Studdard to Perform at 2013 Women's Image Network Awards|url = https://finance.yahoo.com/news/david-foster-ruben-studdard-perform-214820452.html|website = Yahoo Finance|accessdate = 2015-12-07}}</ref> Cecilia DeMille Presley grand daughter to [[Cecil B. DeMille|Cecil DeMille]], Ambassador [[Swanee Hunt]] and Rosalind Jarrett were all honored, while [[Oprah Winfrey|Oprah]] and [[Kerry Washington]] were nominees, among others.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Oprah Winfrey, Kerry Washington Among Women's Image Awards Nominees|url = http://edit.hollywoodreporter.com/news/oprah-winfrey-kerry-washington-womens-648247|website = The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> Presenters included [[Anne Heche]], [[Collette Burson]], [[Kelsey Scott Conover|Kelsey Scott]], [[Yolanda Foster]], [[Kathy Connell]] ([[Screen Actors Guild Award|SAG AWARDS]]), [[Carlos Gómez (actor)|Carlos Gomez]] and [[Kearann Giovanni]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Women's Image Network Awards|url = http://www.thewinawards.com/15_WIN_Honorees.html|website = www.thewinawards.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-Dogouh-j2o Honroee Ambassador Swanee Hunt Arrival] In 2012, WIN approached its gender parity goal with humor by creating a logline [http://www.thewinawards.com/Media.html SEE US IN 3D, NOT JUST DOUBLE D, which many WIN nominees recorded including Selena Gomez and Jane Lynch.] Because if women and girls are portrayed well in the media, girls and women everywhere may one day be well-treated.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Women's Image Network|url = http://www.thewinawards.com/history.html|website = www.thewinawards.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/minglemediatv/sets/72157625864587974/with/5371297925/]

== The Women's Image Awards 16 ==
The show opened with a posthumous [[Joan Rivers]] tribute and featured guest comics [[Brittany Furlan]] and [[T. J. Miller]] who discussed and demonstrated how Joan influenced their comedy. WIN also honored filmmakers [[Lauren Paul]] and [[Molly Thompson]], with its first Community Service tribute for having created ''[[Finding Kind]]'', a documentary film about middle school female bullying. Their film launched a movement and school program based upon the powerful belief in KINDness, that brings awareness and healing to the negative and lasting effects of girl-against-girl crime. Wife of ''[[Breaking Bad]]'' star [[Aaron Paul]], Lauren was bullied in middle school and contemplated suicide.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Aaron Paul's Wife Lauren: I Was Bullied to Brink of Suicide as a Kid|url = http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20805474,00.html|website = PEOPLE.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref>
In 2014, [[Grey's Anatomy]] star, [[Chandra Wilson]] won a directing award.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wetpaint.com/chandra-wilson-wins-womens-award-839540/|title = Grey's Anatomy Chandra Wilson wins Women's Image Network Directing Award|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Wilson|first = Chandra}}</ref> [[Julia Roberts]], [[Whoopi Goldberg]] and [[Cicely Tyson]] were nominees.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Cicely Tyson, Whoopi Goldberg, Joan Rivers and Julia Roberts Nominated for Women's Image Network Awards|url = http://www.playbill.com/news/article/cicely-tyson-whoopi-goldberg-joan-rivers-and-julia-roberts-nominated-for-womens-image-network-awards-334354|website = Playbill|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> [[Melissa Rivers]], (who was also nominated as a producer) attended to accept a posthumous WIN award for her mother, [[Joan Rivers]], who competed and won in the OUTSTANDING REALITY SERIES category for ''[[Fashion Police]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Joan Rivers Gets Posthumous Award Nomination|url = http://www.eonline.com/news/593397/joan-rivers-gets-posthumous-women-s-image-network-award-nomination-for-fashion-police|website = E! Online|accessdate = 2015-12-07}}</ref> Fashion designer [[Sophie Simmons]] collaborated with WIN to promote self-confidence with her Twitter campaign, 'Send Us Your Selfie' which advanced fashion as means for self-esteem.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Breakaway Daily Exclusive: Sophie Tweed-Simmons & Women’s Image Network Promote Self Confidence & Empowerment with "Seek Your Selfie"|url = http://breakawaydaily.com/post/104788581605/breakaway-daily-exclusive-sophie-tweed-simmons|website = breakawaydaily.com|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> Baroness [[Kimberly Moore]] received its Humanitarian Honor.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Kimberly Moore Foundation {{!}} Delivering Hope and Happiness!|url = http://www.kimberlymoorefoundation.org/#!awards-honors/c1cyw|website = Kimberly Moore Foundation {{!}} Delivering Hope and Happiness!|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> Writer [[Caprice Crane]] (daughter of [[Tina Louise]] (''[[Gilligan's Island]]'')) and comic [[Gary Shapiro (journalist)|Gary Shapiro]], co-hosted.

==The Women's Image Awards 17==
The 17th Women's Image Awards ceremony was held at Royce Hall UCLA on February 10, 2016. Philanthropist and activist [[Irena Medavoy]] and documentary filmmaker [[Abigail Disney]] both accepted Woman of the Year tributes.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.prlog.org/12400374-womens-image-network-announces-irena-medavoy-woman-of-the-year-honoree.html|title = Women's Image Network Announces Irena Medavoy Woman of the Year Honoree|date = 6 December 2015|accessdate = 7 December 2015|website = www.prlog.org|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Women’s Image Network Announces Abigail Disney Woman of the Year Honoree {{!}} PRLog|url = http://www.prlog.org/12516199-womens-image-network-announces-abigail-disney-woman-of-the-year-honoree.html|website = www.prlog.org|accessdate = 2015-12-07}}</ref>
The [[Starz]] series ''[[Outlander (TV series)|Outlander]]'' received five nominations, including a nomination in the Drama Series category. [[Caitriona Balfe]], who plays the leading character in the show, also received a nomination in the Actress Drama Series category.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.scotlandnow.dailyrecord.co.uk/lifestyle/caitriona-balfe-outlander-among-nominees-6854233|title = Catriona Balfe and Outlander among nominees for Women's Image Network Awards 2015|date = 18 November 2015|accessdate = 7 December 2015|website = ScotlandNow - For Scots Everywhere|publisher = www.scotlandnow.dailyrecord.co.uk|last = |first = }}</ref>
[[Fox Searchlight Pictures|Fox Searchlight]]'s ''[[He Named Me Malala]]'' also received two nominations, including Best Documentary and Best Producer. Fox Searchlight also received nominations for ''[[Mistress America]]'', ''[[Far from the Madding Crowd (2015 film)|Far from the Madding Crowd]]'', ''[[Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (film)|Me and Earl and the Dying Girl]]'', and ''Brooklyn''. [[20th Century Fox Television|Twentieth Century Fox]] received nominations for ''New Girl'', ''[[Modern Family]]'', ''Empire'', and ''Fresh Off the Boat''. [[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]] received a nomination for a role played by [[Emmanuelle Chriqui|Emmanuelle Chriqu]] in ''Killing Jesus''.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://3blmedia.com/News/Fox-Film-and-TV-Receive-Womens-Image-Award-Nominations-Positive-Portrayals-Women|title = Fox Film and TV Receive Women's Image Award Nominations for Positive Portrayals of Women|date = 23 November 2015|accessdate = 7 December 2015|website = 3BL Media - News and Content Distribution For Innovative Companies|publisher = www.3blmedia.com|last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://celebrityphotos.co/photos/emmanuelle-chriqui-17th-annual-womens-image-awards|title=Emmanuelle Chriqui - 17th Annual Women’s Image Awards|website=celebrityphotos.co|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref>
Hosted by [[Carol Leifer]], other guests included honorees, [[Irena Medavoy]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/5-questions-win-awards-honoree-863876|title=5 Questions With WIN Awards Honoree Irena Medavoy|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> and filmmaker, [[Abigail Disney]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/womens-image-awards-honoree-abigail-disney-its-oscarssowhite-and-oscarssomale/|title=Women's Image Awards' Abigal Disney on #OscarsSoMale|website=TheWrap|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/abigail-disney-irena-medavoy-honored-864417] who is the "Armor of Light" director, who said at the show: "It's time for women to start asserting themselves in media. The filmmaker, One of the Women's Image Awards' Women of the Year, says women need to work together and promote each other in order to overcome the challenges facing women in the entertainment industry and in society as a whole".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/abigail-disney-irena-medavoy-honored-864417|title=A Disney movie by another name|website=Examiner.com|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref>
The film, MAKERS: Women Who Make America won in its Outstanding Documentary Category. [http://www.makers.com/about Women's Image Award: Outstanding Documentary for MAKERS: Women Who Make America]
Other guests included [[Yue-Sai Kan]], [[Francesca Eastwood]], [[Frances Fisher]], [[Joyce Giraud]], [[Breeda Wool]], [[Sam Elliott]], [[Mark Steines]], [[Mark Burnett]], [[Roma Downey]], [[Nzingha Stewart]], [[Marti Noxon]], [[Olivia d'Abo]], [[Quincy Jones|Quincy]], [[Catherine Bach]], [[Outlander series|Ronald. T. (Chile) [[Sony Pictures Classics]] |}
Although Women's Image Netwrok is a 501(c)3 non-profit, it has also supported several other charities including The Mary Magdalene Foundation, Women’s Care Cottage, The Mission, Gilda’s Club, The American Cancer Society. WIN supports charities whose efforts range from fighting homeless, rehabilitating prostitutes, curing HIV/AIDS and cancer, eliminating poverty, biodiversity conservation and wild animal rescue.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The WIN Awards 2010 Honors Sophia Loren Entry Deadline August 31st|url = https://www.worldpulse.com/fr/node/11197|website = World Pulse|accessdate = 2015-12-08}}</ref> In some years, proceeds from the WIN Awards Gala have been used to fund other WIN events, such as in 2006 when the charity created the Day in the Life program designed to mentor at-risk girls.<ref name="Stratton">{{cite web|last = Stratton|first = P. J.|title = Mirren takes two Win Awards for QE I & II in different films|url = http://www.hollywoodtoday.net/2006/11/23/mirren-takes-two-win-awards-for-qe-i-ii-in-different-films/|publisher = Hollywood Today|date = 23 November 2006|accessdate = 8 October 2012}}</ref>
==Women's Image Network Advisory Board== Since its inception, WIN has benefited from guidance from seasoned industry professionals Current (a few former and deceased) WIN Advisory Board members include: [[Tamara Asseyev]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0085542/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Todd Black], [[Helen Gurley Brown]], [[David Brown (producer)|David Brown]], [[Blake Edwards]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0287116/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Eizabeth Forsythe-Hailey], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0368552/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Elaine Hastings Edell], [[Mariette Hartley]], [[Arthur Hiller]], [[Henry Jaglom]], [[Norman Jewison]], [[Alan Landsburg]], [[Sherry Lansing]]. [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0516056/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Lauren Lloyd], [[Bryan Lourd]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0526991/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Dan Lupovitz], [[Amanda Mackey Johnson]], [[Laurence Mark]], [[Jayne Meadows]], Baroness Kimberly Moore, [[Peter Newman (film producer)|Peter Newman]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0657499/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Bonnie Palef], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0683579/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Sarah Pillsbury], [[Polly Platt]], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0707475/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Peggy Rajski], [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1099756/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Alyse Rosenberg], [[Fred Schepisi]], [[Linda Shayne]], [[Lauren Shuler Donner]], [[George Stevens, Jr.|George Stevens, Jr]]., [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0829162/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Allyn Stewart], [[Ellen Travolta]] and [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005572/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 Lili Fini Zanuck].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Women's Image Network Awards|url = http://www.thewinawards.com/advisors.html|website = www.thewinawards.com|accessdate = 2015-12-09}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Yetu Microfinance Bank PLC| logo = Yetu Microfinance PLC.png| type = Public| traded_as = {{DARSE|YETU}} | foundation = 1997| location = [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]] | key_people = '''Altemius Millinga'''
[[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]]| num_employees = | assets = US$6.80 million (TZS:15.52 billion) (2017)| revenue = | industry = [[Financial Services]]| products = [[Loans]], [[Savings]]| website = {{URL|http://www.yetumfplc.co.tz/}} }} '''Yetu Microfinance Bank Plc.''' (YETU) is a [[microfinance]] bank in [[Tanzania]]. It is the first microfinance institution to be listed in the [[Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.dse.co.tz/content/listed-securities|title=Listed Securities {{!}} Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange PLC|website=www.dse.co.tz|access-date=2016-07-05}} ''Yetu'' is a [[Swahili language|Swahili]] word meaning ''Ours''. ==Overview== YETU Microfinance Bank PLC is a bank dedicated to provide financial services to the unbanked and under banked people of Tanzania.The bank offers credit products, such as solidarity group loans for clients who are organized into groups whose members serve as informal bank and cross guarantee each other’s loans; Mavuno loan products to afford members of solidarity group loan who have reached a loan ceiling of TZS 3 million and would like to borrower on individual capacity; small and medium enterprises loan products, including export and import, car, business/shop improvement, business capital, and processing and manufacturing loans; SRI agricultural loans; mixed farming loans to smallholder farmers for financing various crops; and instant loans, as well as education loans. Its deposit products comprise compulsory (collateral) savings; and voluntary deposits. ==History== Yetu Microfinance Bank PLC was born out of the transformation of Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO), an NGO which was established in 1997 and successfully managed microfinance business on a sustainable basis. == Corporate Affairs == The [[Board of Directors]] of the company comprises six individuals. The [[Chairman]] is one of the five non-Executive Directors. The current Chairman is Ernest Ndimbo and the current [[Managing Director]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]] (CEO), is Altemius Millinga.{{Cite web|url=http://www.yetumfplc.co.tz/?page_id=48|title=Board of directors – Yetu Microfinance PLC|website=www.yetumfplc.co.tz|access-date=2016-07-05}} ===Ownership=== YOSEFO is a major shareholder of YETU Microfinance Bank PLC. YETU Microfinance has taken over from YOSEFO all the branches, agencies and financial services delivery centers and the 28,000 loyal clients. Yetu Microfinance sold 6,223,380 shares at the price of 500/- and managed to raise 3.1bn/- collected from 14,273 subscribers through an IPO.{{Cite web|url=http://dailynews.co.tz/index.php/business/47816-yetu-microfinance-formally-goes-public|title=Yetu Microfinance formally goes public|last=Reporter|first=DAILY NEWS|website=dailynews.co.tz|access-date=2016-07-05}} ==Branch and Agency Network== {{asof|January 2016}}, Yetu Microfinance Bank PLC maintains a network of branches and agencies at the following locations:{{Cite web|url=http://www.yetumfplc.co.tz/?page_id=105|title=Our Branches – Yetu Microfinance PLC|website=www.yetumfplc.co.tz|access-date=2016-07-05}} # '''Head Office''' - [[Dar es Salaam]] # Mbagala Branch - [[Temeke District]], [[Dar es Salaam]] # Mzizima Branch - [[Ilala District]], [[Dar es Salaam]] # Mngeta Branch - [[Kilombero District]], [[Morogoro]]. # Zanzibar Branch - [[Zanzibar]] # Kilwa Agency - [[Kilwa]]. # Lindi Agency - [[Lindi]] # Lumo Agency - [[Temeke District]], [[Dar es Salaam]] ==See also== * [[Microfinance in Tanzania]] * [[Dar es Salaam Stock Exchange]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.yetumfplc.co.tz/ Website of Yetu Microfinance PLC] [[Category:Microfinance companies of Africa]] [[Category:Business in Africa]] [[Category:Finance in Tanzania]] [[Category:Finance in Africa]]
